vedasPage1.title: Ancient Hindu scriptures considered divine revelations, forming the foundation of Sanatan Dharma.
vedasPage1.intro: The Vedas (from the Sanskrit root 'vid' — to know) are the oldest stratum of South Asian sacred literature. Composed in Vedic Sanskrit and preserved through conservative oral transmission, they shaped ritual practice, social ideals, and early Indian thought.
vedasPage1.historicalText: Scholars estimate that the core hymns were composed between the second and first millennia BCE. The texts were preserved by priestly lineages through mnemonic recitation techniques before being committed to writing.

structure.samhitas: Samhitās — collections of hymns and mantras used in ritual.
structure.brahmanas: Brahmaṇas — prose explanations of ritual procedures and meanings.
structure.aranyakas: Āraṇyakas — transitional texts often linked to forest teachings and contemplative practice.
structure.upanishads: Upaniṣads — philosophical portions focusing on knowledge (jñāna) and the nature of reality.

vedasPage1.fourVedasTitle: The four Vedas and their emphases
vedasPage1.shakhasText: Each Veda branched into multiple śākhā (recensional schools) with their own orderings and ritual practices; only a subset of śākhā survive in manuscript and printed form.
vedasPage1.sagesText: Traditional accounts name ṛṣis (sages) such as Vasiṣṭha and Viśvāmitra as hymn authors; later redactors organized the material into the canonical fourfold structure.
vedasPage1.languageText: Vedic Sanskrit differs from Classical Sanskrit in phonology and grammar and employs meters such as triṣṭubh and gāyatrī; these features help date and classify the corpus.
vedasPage1.themesText: The Vedas address ritual efficacy, cosmology, social order, and the nature of ultimate reality; the Upaniṣads in particular influence later Indian philosophy.

deep.title: Deep dive — dating, authorship, composition and purpose
deep.whenText: Dating the Vedas is complex because they were transmitted orally long before surviving in written manuscripts. Current scholarly consensus places the core Rigvedic hymns roughly between c. 1500–1200 BCE, with later composition and accretion continuing through the first millennium BCE. These ranges are best understood as broad windows rather than precise dates.
deep.whoText: Traditionally the Vedas are ascribed to seers (ṛṣis) and priestly lineages. Names like Vasiṣṭha and Viśvāmitra indicate poetic or priestly families rather than single modern-style authors. Composition was multi-generational and communal.
deep.whatTitle: What is in the Vedas and how are they organized?
whatList: Samhitā material: Hymns and mantras used in liturgy — typically the oldest linguistic layers.
Brahmaṇa prose: Explanatory ritual prose and procedural exegesis for priests.
Āraṇyaka texts: Transitional and contemplative passages associated with forest practice.
Upaniṣadic teachings: Philosophical inquiries into ātman, Brahman, and liberation.
deep.purposeTitle: What was the primary purpose of the Vedas?
purposeList: Ritual efficacy: mantras and procedures intended to produce ritual results.
Preservation of social order: reinforcing roles and norms.
Knowledge and memory: storing genealogies, myths and ritual know-how.
Speculative inquiry: philosophical reflection, especially in the Upaniṣads.
Practical concerns: healing and household rites in the Atharvaveda.
deep.preservationTitle: How were the texts preserved so accurately?
deep.preservationText: Highly formalized oral techniques (padapāṭha, krama, ghana) and strict phonetic training produced exceptional fidelity in transmission.
deep.scholarshipText: Philology, comparative linguistics, archaeology, and textual criticism together help scholars analyze composition, chronology, and social context; many questions remain open.

rigveda.title: Rigveda
rigveda.summary: The Rigveda is the oldest Veda: a hymnal corpus used in sacrificial rituals and rich in early mythic reflection.
rigveda.content: Collections of hymns (ṛc) addressed to deities like Agni and Indra; complex meters and archaic language make the Rigveda a primary source for early Vedic religion.

samaveda.title: Samaveda
samaveda.summary: The Samaveda is primarily a collection arranged for chanting; its musical forms give ritual performance a melodic structure.
samaveda.content: Verses from the Rigveda adapted for melodic recitation (sāman); the Samaveda highlights liturgical music and chant tradition.

yajurveda.title: Yajurveda
yajurveda.summary: The Yajurveda contains the procedural formulas and sacrificial instructions used by priests during rites.
yajurveda.content: Textual recensions (śukla and kṛṣṇa) organize mantras and explanatory prose for the performance of yajña.

atharvaveda.title: Atharvaveda
atharvaveda.summary: The Atharvaveda includes spells, charms, and domestic rites addressing everyday concerns alongside ritual material.
atharvaveda.content: Containing incantations, healing formulas, and household practices, the Atharvaveda complements the sacrificial focus of the other Vedas.

puranasPage.title: The Puranas — mythology, cosmology, and lineages
puranasPage.intro: The Puranas are a large corpus of narrative literature that systematizes cosmology, genealogies, mythic histories, and devotional material. Composed over many centuries, the Puranas bridge classical Hindu thought, ritual practice, and popular devotion.

structure.cosmology: Cosmology and cosmogony: descriptions of creation, cyclical time, and the universe's structure.
structure.genealogies: Genealogies (vamsa): lineages of gods, sages, kings, and dynasties.
structure.mythicNarrative: Mythic narratives and didactic stories conveying moral, theological and ritual lessons.
structure.rituals: Ritual prescriptions and local rites incorporated into narrative frameworks.

major.bhagavata: Bhagavata Purana — devotional (bhakti) theology centred on Krishna and stories of the avatar tradition.
major.padma: Padma Purana — extensive cosmological narratives, pilgrimage guides, and regional religious practice.
major.vishnu: Vishnu Purana — genealogies and the theological role of Vishnu as preserver; syncretic historical material.
major.shiva: Shiva Purana — legends, ritual acts, and the theological development of Śaiva traditions.

puranasPage.commentaryText: The Puranas exist in many redactions and regional recensions. Their composition spans late antiquity to the early medieval period; later interpolations reflect devotional movements and local practices.

biblio.doniger: Wendy Doniger — The Hindus: An Alternative History (context and readings)
biblio.atta: R.C. Hazra — Studies in the Puranic Literature (historical survey)

bhagavata.title: Bhagavata Purana
bhagavata.summary: The Bhagavata Purana is a devotional Purana centered on Krishna's life, theology of bhakti, and ethical teachings through stories and parables.
bhagavata.content: Includes cosmology, genealogies, and extensive narratives of Krishna's childhood, youth, and teachings; foundational for many bhakti movements.

padma.title: Padma Purana
padma.summary: A large Purana with material on pilgrimage (tirtha), cosmology and ritual practice. It preserves localized liturgical traditions and pilgrimage guides.
padma.content: Contains sections on dharma, rites, and geographical-pilgrimage material that became important for medieval religious practice.

shastrasPage.title: The Shastras — technical, ethical, and artistic treatises
shastrasPage.intro: 'Shastra' denotes authoritative treatises on specialized subjects: law, statecraft, architecture, dramaturgy, and ritual. These texts shaped classical Indian institutions and practical arts.

sections.dharma: Dharmaśāstras — legal and ethical manuals governing social duties, law and ritual obligations.
sections.artha: Arthaśāstra — statecraft, economics, and practical politics as articulated in manuals of governance.
sections.vastu: Vastu and architectural treatises on building, town-planning and auspicious design.
sections.natya: Nāṭyaśāstra — dramaturgy, performance, and aesthetics; a foundational manual for classical theatre and dance.

shastrasPage.influenceText: Shastra literature generated extensive commentary traditions: jurists, grammarians, architects and rhetoricians produced glosses and manuals that adapted core teachings to local contexts.

biblio.olivelle: Patrick Olivelle — Dharmasutras and Dharmashastra studies (selected translations)
biblio.kautilya: R. Shamasastry (ed.): Kautilya's Arthashastra (translations and commentary)
biblio.natya: Manomohan Ghosh — The Nāṭyaśāstra (introduction and selected readings)

dharma.title: Dharmaśāstras
dharma.summary: Legal and ethical treatises articulating duties (dharma), social order, and procedures for dispute resolution.
dharma.content: From the Dharmasutras to later Dharmaśāstras, these texts influenced law, ritual prescriptions, and social norms across South Asia.

artha.title: Arthaśāstra
artha.summary: Treatises on governance, administration, revenue and diplomacy; the Arthashastra is the most famous exemplar.
artha.content: Covers practical aspects of statecraft including espionage, taxation, and military strategy; later commentaries adapt it to changing polities.
